Award.AwardTitle: 33rd Ohio State-Denison Mathematics Conference on the Theory of Groups and Rings
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports travel for keynote speakers and young researchers attending the 33rd Ohio State-Denison Mathematics Conference, May 13-15, 2016, at the Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio. The meeting is focused on the theory of groups and rings and will attract top mathematicians from around the world, in addition to graduate students and post-doctoral researchers from all parts of the US. The conference will foster new collaborations, introduce graduate students to established researchers and cutting-edge techniques, provide young mathematicians with opportunities to present their work, and encourage participation by researchers belonging to under-represented groups.

This year the Ohio State-Denison Mathematics Conference features keynote talks devoted to GK-dimension of algebras, universal constructions in rings, and embedding results in groups. There will also be contributed talks on a wide range of other currently active areas of research, including clean rings, Leavitt path algebras, projective and injective modules, and solvable groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project was to organize the 33rd biannual Ohio State-Denison Mathematics Conference, intended to bring together a diverse group of leading international experts in the field of algebra, specifically ring and group theory, along with young mathematicians. This conference was initiated in the 1960s by Hans Zassenhaus, and has since become an important national meeting that attracts top researchers in the field from around the world and often fosters new collaborations.

The 33rd Ohio State-Denison Mathematics Conference took place during May 13-15, 2016 at the Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio. The conference was attended by at least 60 mathematicians, of whom 43 gave talks. The countries represented by the participants include Canada, Egypt, France, India, Israel, Mexico, Russia, South Korea, Slovenia, Spain, and the United Kingdom, in addition to the United States (which was represented by 46 mathematicians).

This year’s conference was dedicated to George Bergman (UC Berkeley) in celebration of his 75th birthday, which helped attract such attendance. The participants included the highly distinguished researchers Vladimir Bavula (University of Sheffield), Jason Bell (University of Waterloo), Gary Birkenmeier (University of Louisiana at Lafayette), Victor Camillo (University of Iowa), Kenneth Goodearl (UC Santa Barbara), Birge Huisgen- Zimmermann (UC Santa Barbara), S. K. Jain (Ohio University), Tsit-Yuen Lam (UC Berkeley), and Andre Leroy (Universite d’Artois). The talks at the conference sparked many lively discussions among the attendees, which are likely to lead to successful collab- orations, producing significant new research in the field. Based on the numerous positive comments received by the organizers in person and by email, the attendees were very happy with the outcome.

The participants of the conference included 11 Ph. D. students and several postdoctoral students, who gave 12 of the talks. This afforded them the opportunity to interact with some of the world’s leading experts in the field and receive commentary on their work. Due to the close proximity of the conference location to the Ohio University Center of Ring Theory and its Applications, a significant number of graduate students and postdoctoral students were able to attend at low cost. They were given the opportunity to present their work at a conference attended by the aforementioned luminaries because of the Ohio State-Denison tradition of accepting all requests to speak.

Additionally, some of the talks, especially the plenary ones, gave broad overviews of various subfields of algebra, discussed currently open problems, and introduced new techniques, providing young mathematicians with a good perspective on the state of the subject, along with tools for future work.
